I am testing a method "changeSignOnPassword" which takes (userid, 
oldpw, newpw) as parameters. When userid is not found the method will 
throw UserIdNotFoundException. When oldpw is incorrect it will throw 
SecurityException. When oldpw or newpw is too short it will throw 
PwTooShortException. When newpw is the same as oldpw it will throw 
PwSameException. 

Since all expected exceptions must be tested, a suggested solution is 
to write 6 separate test cases, one for each different variant:
- testChangeSignOnPasswordOK
- testChangeSignOnPasswordUserIdNotFound
- testChangeSignOnPasswordOldPwNotValid
- testChangeSignOnPasswordOldPwTooShort
- testChangeSignOnPasswordNewPwTooShort
- testChangeSignOnPasswordPwSame

I am hesitant to repeat the same test case code, changing the input 
data, and using different assertions in different catch blocks for 
different variants. It could be a maintenance nightmare with all 
these repetitions.

Is there a better way to handle the variants?
I am thinking of the possibility of just having one test case which 
will be run multiple times, using a different set of input data, and 
compare the result against a different set of expected output data, 
thus maintaining only one single test case code. 
Any comment or suggestion?

Val Danukarjanto.
